data.name: para
data.content: A force does not just push or pull. It produces measurable physical effects. These effects appear as changes in speed, changes in direction, or changes in shape.

data.name: para
data.content: When a force acts on an object, it can increase its speed, decrease its speed, or bring it to rest. Any change in speed is called acceleration.

data.name: para
data.content: According to Newton’s Second Law, force causes acceleration. The acceleration produced depends on the magnitude of the force and the mass of the object.

data.name: para
data.content: A force can change the direction of motion even if the speed remains constant. When direction changes, velocity changes. This is also acceleration.

data.name: para
data.content: When a bat hits a moving ball, the ball’s direction changes. The applied force redirects the motion of the ball.

data.name: para
data.content: A force can also change the shape of an object. When an object is compressed, stretched, or bent, its shape changes due to applied force.

data.name: para
data.content: If an object returns to its original shape after the force is removed, the deformation is elastic. If it does not return, the deformation is permanent.

data.name: subtitle
data.content: A force can change speed, direction, or shape. These changes explain how motion and physical transformations occur in the world around us.
